data.title: Hide private methods/properties
data.body:
I would like to ask if it was possible to add a feature which hide private methods/properties of intellisense out of the class in which they are defined in JavaScript ?
We could determinate a private method/properties when it begin with an underscore or/and with the jsdoc.

Thanks for all your work ;)

data.title: [Tasks 2.0.0] Wrapping output in terminal when Panel is hidden
data.body:
Hi,

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra

when I run my "test" task in terminal and Panel is hidden, then the output in the terminal is wrapped, it looks like this (new line after 80 chars):
```
Chrome 56.0.2924 (Mac OS X 10.12.3): Executed 1 of 6546 (skipped 6545) SUCCESS (
2.99 secs / 0.015 secs)
```

But when I run the task with opened Panel, then the output is as it should be - non-wrapped. It looks like this:
```
Chrome 56.0.2924 (Mac OS X 10.12.3): Executed 1 of 6546 (skipped 6545) SUCCESS (3.122 secs / 0.018 secs)
```

It would be just a styling issue, but the bigger problem is, that if one has a custom `problemMatcher` which normally matches one line and it is wrapped by hidden Panel, then the matcher never finishes and no other task can be run (and "slashes" indicator \/\/is the bottom left of the Code is spinning and spinning and ...). Once it also crashed whole Code.

My `problemMatcher` to matching problems generated by Chrome when running JS tests by Karma runner:
```
"problemMatcher": {
    "fileLocation": "absolute",
    "pattern": [
        {
            "regexp": "(Expected.+\\.)$",
            "message": 1
        },
        {
            "regexp": "\\s+at\\s+.+\\s+\\((.+\\.js):(\\d+):(\\d+)\\)$",
            "file": 1,
            "line": 2,
            "column": 3
        }
    ]
}
```

Thanks.

data.title: Support title from xterm.js
data.body:
From @pharmmd-rich in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22319

> The dropdown list currently displays a list of processes, however, I like giving my terminals custom names in OS-X. The drop down list does not appear to honor these names. (they are set using: printf '\033]0;title\007'".

Open to PRs, we will want to handle `xterm.on('title', listener)` inside `TerminalInstance` and use that over the pty name if it's set. Currently I'm assuming this will only fire if the user has set up a title they want to use, whether of not the event is guarenteed to fire on new terminals might change my thinking on how it works.

data.title: [Themes] Selection inside "wordHighlight"ed word does not use a proper color
data.body:
Hi,

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra

When you have a custom theme which defines a custom color for `wordHighlight` (i.e. for occurrences of e.g. local variable inside a function), then if you click on such variable and when it has a matching usage inside the scope, then `wordHighlight` color is properly set to all occurrences. 

So far so good. But if you start "selection" (by mouse drag) inside that "active" variable, then the "selected" part of the variable is NOT replaced by "selection" color.

It does not work in [Sample Light Theme](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/blob/master/theme-sample/Sample_Light.tmTheme) either. But it works in natively provided themes (also tried it in Quiet Light).

Thanks!

data.title: Find and Replace is a bad experience.
data.body:
I have a proposal. I think that global find and replace would be much more usable if it was laid out horizontally. Preferably where things like the "PROBLEMS", "OUTPUT", and "DEBUG CONSOLE" are.

I love Atoms and Sublimes find and replace for lots of different reasons but this is honestly my biggest hangup with vscode.

So here are what some of the competition does.

Atom (arguable my favorite experience and the most concise) ---- Horizontal and Vertical
![screen shot 2017-03-09 at 11 30 36 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5297942/23764721/c6fbe91e-04bb-11e7-96b0-c686bf11d525.png)

Sublime (Cool but once you search you lose you search box) ---- exclusively Horizontal then Vertical
![screen shot 2017-03-09 at 11 24 03 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5297942/23764930/854d476e-04bc-11e7-827d-a5b5955f9837.png)

after search
![screen shot 2017-03-09 at 11 32 48 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5297942/23764952/96d61ccc-04bc-11e7-908f-161d0166ac92.png)

And Webstorm I feel like they gave up and just made it work.
You get a separate popup
![screen shot 2017-03-09 at 11 25 08 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5297942/23765034/fccd7282-04bc-11e7-806e-8ec01292a70a.png)

then that goes away after you search and you get results (In my opinion they are muddy and hard to read) Horizontal
![screen shot 2017-03-09 at 11 33 26 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5297942/23765080/2bf8ee56-04bd-11e7-9b96-41e114d09b85.png)


THE POINT
The point is most other editor at least show search results in a Horizontal layout. This is for good reason. The results are much more digestible.

Here is what my results look like most of the time. (all squished on the side)
![screen shot 2017-03-09 at 11 44 37 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5297942/23765247/ce7cc206-04bd-11e7-8340-10a1062273e4.png)

The funny thing about this.. When showing search in the documentation for vscode it looks more horizontal. I think the reason why is it creates a better user experience.
https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/codebasics#_search-across-files
![codebasics_search](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5297942/23765606/f3baeab0-04be-11e7-952d-c823eb4d326a.png)


So my issue is I think I could probably make a plugin to do this a little better but I wanted to see if this is the direction vscode will be going in the future or if it should be done as a plugin.

data.title: versioning and release practices
data.body:
I'm confused on the versioning and release practices for VSCode.

- My locally installed executable version is currently at 1.10.2 (via an in-app update from the initially installed version of 1.10.1).
- The latest version that's been tagged is 1.10.1.
- The latest version in the github releases is 1.10.1.
- The latest version in the release/1.10 branch (according to package.json) is 1.10.2.
- The version in the master branch (according to package.json) is 1.11.0.

What's the process or protocol by which a release is sent out to clients if it's not related to git tags or github releases?  I've seen [this wiki page](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Release-Process), but it may be outdated based on what I'm seeing in the tags, branches, and releases currently.

data.title: Double-clicking to select text in an editor should respect casing (as developers see casing)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: OS X (El Capitan) 10.11.6
- Language: Agnostic

Consider the following text samples:

1) messageQueue (camel)
2) message-queue (kabob)
3) MessageQueue (Pascal)
4) message_queue (C)

As it stands now, when I double-click text formatted as #2 above, "words" within the text select independently of the rest of the text, as we would expect (the hyphen provides a natural breaking point).

But that doesn't happen in the caseS of #1 , #3, and #4.  Yet, from a developer's perspective, there's no difference really.

It would be nice if there were a setting that would allow us to treat cased words within text (with no intervening whitespace) as separate "words".  In the case of #1 above, for example, double-clicking within "Queue" would select just Queue, etc.  Additionally, in a manner similar to clicking in Microsoft Word, if we triple-click, then the entire text would be selected without respect to casing.

I seem to recall being able to do this years ago in Visual Studio (though I think we had to have the ReSharper extension).

Thank you for your consideration...and for a great job!

Eric

data.title: Thoughts regarding the integrated terminal
data.body:
First of all, great work on the integrated terminal everyone!  I tried it again recently after not using for a while and it has improved significantly.  That being said, I have a couple thoughts regarding the look, feel, and key usage of the terminal.

1) Rather than having the tabs for Problems, Output, Debug Console, and Terminal be at the top, why not put them at the side or bottom and then convert the terminal drop down list to tabs?  This would allow 1 click to switch between tabs vs 2.
2) The dropdown list currently displays a list of processes, however, I like giving my terminals custom names in OS-X.  The drop down list does not appear to honor these names. (they are set using: `printf '\033]0;title\007'"`.
3) It would be great if you could use a custom theme just for the terminal.  While I use the default theme for VSCode, I would like the background to be black for the terminal to provide cleaner separation.
4) When closing a terminal and the default shell isn't the current active process, it would be great if you could pop up a warning message.  I've accidentally closed terminals with running processes in them...leaving the process orphaned.  I then have to go in and kill the process manually. 

Just a few thoughts.  Thanks for an awesome editor!

data.title: Move CancellationToken into own npm package
data.body:
JavaScript does not have a native way to represent cancellation of async operaions, and there have been many discussions and failed attempts to fold this into the language. [The most promising tc39 proposal](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-cancelable-promises) has been withdrawn (which used `CancellationToken`s), bluebird has cancellable promises and RxJS Observables are cancellable.

VS Code uses `CancellationToken` from C# for cancellation. They are also used in the TS Server, vscode-jsonrpc and vscode-languageserver. Currently, this comes down to just two classes: `CancellationToken` and `CancellationTokenSource`. These classes seem to be duplicated in the code of every of the above examples. This imposes a problem, because one of the biggest concerns with cancellations is what a promise should resolve to when it is cancelled - typically it is rejected with a `CancelledError`, and code needs to differentiate between a true error and a cancellation in eg `catch` blocks. The TS Server for example does define its own `OperationCancelledException` (which weirdly doesn't inherit from `Error`). If every API defines its own classes and there is no uniform interface, it is impossible to do proper checks for CancellationErrors in catch blocks (eg with `instanceof` or some other type check).

Adding to that, the implementation is lacking basic features that were discussed in the tc39 proposal and available in C#, for example composition of CancelTokens. It is a basic use case to combine multiple CancellationTokens, creating a new CancellationTokenSource from an existing CancellationToken or `throwIfRequested()`.

Moving cancellation into a standalone open source library that anyone could use would greatly improve the interoperability between APIs and allow to easily add more features that improve usage ergonomics.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create file 'source.jsx' with following content:

2. In the same folder create 'dest.js' with following content:
`import TestClass from './source.jsx';`
3. In this file right click on `TestClass`, select 'Go to Definition'
4. `No definition found for 'Test'` suggestion appeared.

But when `source.jsx` is changed to `source.js` in both filename and import statement, suggestion works as expected.

data.title: Inspector protocol ignored when using compounds
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

As discussed in #21883 ...
It doesn't look like setting `protocol` to `inspector` or `auto` works when using `compounds`. If I run the following `DEV` it uses `inspector`, but if I run `DEV/Chrome` it uses `legacy` for `DEV`.

```json
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "DEV",
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "protocol": "inspector",
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/index.js",
      "stopOnEntry": false,
      "args": [
        "dev"
      ]
    },
    {
      "name": "Chrome",
      "type": "chrome",
      "request": "launch",
      "url": "http://localhost:8080",
      "webRoot": "${workspaceRoot}/public",
      "userDataDir": "${env:TEMP}/VSCodeChrome/${workspaceRootFolderName}"
    }
  ],
  "compounds": [
    {
      "name": "DEV/Chrome",
      "configurations": [
        "DEV",
        "Chrome"
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

Also, even when running just `DEV` by itself it executes `node --inspect=12680 --debug-brk index.js dev` instead of the expected `node --inspect=12680 --inspect-brk index.js dev`.

data.title: Feature Request - File open and save as
data.body: Why do we, by default, have to open a new file and then save the file with a name. Won't it make sense to have a feature where you could choose a new file and save as in one step? I never understood why editors never offered a choice to create new file and save as in one step? Maybe its just me but it makes sense to do this in one step instead of two.

data.title: .editorconfig.end_of_line, and previewing files with conflicting eol's, auto modifies file on preview
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create/find file known to have `crlf` eol's
2. Create `.editorconfig` with `end_of_line = lf`
3. Single-click filename to preview
4. File is opened, and then instantly modified automatically

This issue occurs, for example, when on Windows and using `git` to clone a repo from github, which will convert line endings on-the-file to match destination O/S eol preference. If the repo also has an `.editorconfig` with an `eol_of_line` in conflict with O/S preference, the issue becomes prevalent.

Double-clicking a filename will open a dedicated editor tab, but does not automatically modify line endings. File previewing should work the same in that the file is not automatically modified.

data.title: Remote debugging not working again
data.body:
I'm not sure in which version of VSCode remote debugging broke for me. But I know it broke for perhaps within 2 months.

These are the settings I've been using for a long time before it broke(and they have been working for many months):
```
        {
            "name": "Attach Remotely",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "port": 6000,
            "address": "localhost",
            "restart": false,
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "outFiles": [
                "${workspaceRoot}/Build/**/*.js"
            ],
            "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "remoteRoot": "/srv/noelia"
        }
```
I'm using Docker Compose for development:
```
services:
  dev.noelia:
    image: ****
    container_name: dev.noelia
    extra_hosts:
      - "dockerhost:$DOCKERHOST"
    volumes:
      - .:/srv/noelia
      - ~/.bash_history:/root/.bash_history
    ports:
      - "3000:3003"
      - "6000:5858"
```
I'm using Docker for Mac and I have a debugger breaked on entrance. I run a `tcpdump` to ensure the VSCode can reach the node runtime.

```
tcpdump -i eth0 port 5858
tcpdump: verbose output suppressed, use -v or -vv for full protocol decode
listening on eth0, link-type EN10MB (Ethernet), capture size 262144 bytes
16:00:11.189204 IP 172.23.0.1.58520 > 4c1a1942b276.5858: Flags [S], seq 2036585880, win 29200, options [mss 1460,sackOK,TS val 5094367 ecr 0,nop,wscale 7], length 0
16:00:11.189259 IP 4c1a1942b276.5858 > 172.23.0.1.58520: Flags [R.], seq 0, ack 2036585881, win 0, length 0
```

I can confirm it can reach because some packets are showing every time I click on the attach button.

And I'm using Mocha to issue the debug break statement
```
./node_modules/mocha/bin/mocha ./Build/Source/Tests/RunTests.js --timeout 15000 --colors --full-trace --grep LinksCanNavigateToSameLayout --debug-brk
Debugger listening on 127.0.0.1:5858
```

There is no outputted error on VSCode (Debug Console) and when I try to attach to it, it loads a bit and then nothing happens the loading indicator disappears. There are no Debug buttons appearing as usual. 

I tried to attach locally by running the same command and it works. Just remote debugging (in a Docker container) doesn't work for me.

data.title: Breakpoint in collapsed code is visible, but not usable
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise

Steps to Reproduce:

Given:
```js
function f() {
    return 0;
}
```

1. Add a breakpoint at the `return` statement.
2. Collapse the function.
3. The breakpoint is still visible.
4. Right-click on it.
5. This gives me an option to "Add breakpoint". But I want to remove it.
